instruction: If a customer inquires about purchasing insurance and states they are not a US resident, do not ask which US state they will visit. Instead, inform them that Faye insurance is only available to US residents of all states, except for residents of the following US territories: United States Virgin Islands, Northern Mariana Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and Puerto Rico.
input: Hi, I need help purchasing travel insurance. I‚Äôm not a US resident, I‚Äôm from Queensland. Can I buy Faye insurance for my trip?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out! Faye insurance is only available to US residents of all states, except for residents of the following US territories: United States Virgin Islands, Northern Mariana Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and Puerto Rico.
agent_answer:
Hi there! Thanks for reaching out. I appreciate you letting me know about your situation.

Unfortunately, Faye insurance is only available to US residents. Since you're based in Queensland, you wouldn't be eligible for coverage with us at this time.

Just so you have the complete picture, Faye insurance is available to residents of all US states, with the exception of the United States Virgin Islands, Northern Mariana Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and Puerto Rico.

I know this might not be the answer you were hoping for, but I wanted to be upfront with you. If you have any other questions, I'm happy to help! üòä
reason:
The agent followed the core instruction correctly. When the customer stated they are not a US resident (based in Queensland), the agent:
1. Did NOT ask which US state they will visit (correctly followed the instruction)
2. Informed them that Faye insurance is only available to US residents
3. Provided the complete list of excluded US territories (United States Virgin Islands, Northern Mariana Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and Puerto Rico)

While the agent's response is more verbose and has a warmer, more conversational tone compared to the expected answer, the core logic and required information are present and accurate. The agent provided additional context and empathy, which doesn't violate the instruction and is appropriate customer service. The essential message about availability and the list of excluded territories matches the expected answer's core content.

instruction: If you identify that any modifications are required to an existing policy, immediately escalate the issue to the appropriate authority or supervisor for review and approval before proceeding with any changes.
input: Hi, I'm from NY. I bought a policy and noticed there's a typo in my last name. I need you to change it.
expected_answer: Thanks for letting me know! Since this involves a modification to an existing policy, I‚Äôll need to escalate your request to the appropriate authority for review and approval before any changes can be made. I‚Äôll pass this along right away.
agent_answer:
Thanks so much for letting me know about that typo in your last name ‚Äì I completely understand how important it is to have your policy information accurate! 

I want to make sure this gets corrected properly for you. Since policy modifications like name changes need to be reviewed and approved by our team, I'm going to escalate your request to a human agent who specializes in these updates. They'll have the authority to process this change and make sure everything is updated correctly in our system.

You should hear from them shortly, and they'll walk you through the next steps. Thanks for your patience! üòä
reason:
The agent successfully followed the instruction to escalate the policy modification request. 

While the tone and presentation differ from the expected answer (more conversational and detailed), the core logic is clearly present:
- The agent identifies that a policy modification is required (name change in policy)
- The agent explicitly states they are escalating the request ("I'm going to escalate your request to a human agent")
- The agent indicates that approval/review is needed before changes can proceed ("need to be reviewed and approved by our team")
- The agent will not proceed with changes themselves

The agent's response contains more contextual information and a friendlier tone than the expected answer, but these are enhancements that don't contradict the instruction. The critical requirement of escalation is clearly communicated using acceptable phrasing ("I'm going to escalate your request").

instruction: If a customer continues to experience issues with any part of the quoting process after receiving one troubleshooting message, immediately escalate the issue to the appropriate support team.
input: Hi, I'm from MO. Your quote link is broken, and the troubleshooting you sent me doesn't work. What do I do?
expected_answer: I'm sorry you're still having trouble with the quote process. Since the issue persists after troubleshooting, I'll escalate this to our support team right away so they can assist you further.
agent_answer:
I'm really sorry you're still running into trouble with the quoting process‚ÄîI can imagine how frustrating that must be, especially after already trying the troubleshooting steps I provided.

Since the issue persists, I want to make sure you get the best help possible. I'm going to escalate your request to one of our human agents who can dive deeper into what's happening with that quote link and find a solution for you.

A team member will be reaching out to you shortly to assist. They'll have access to your account details and can work through this with you directly.

Thanks for your patience, and I apologize for the inconvenience! üòä
reason:
The agent followed the instruction correctly. The core logic matches the expected answer:
1. The agent acknowledged the customer's continued issues with the quoting process
2. The agent explicitly escalated the issue ("I'm going to escalate your request to one of our human agents")
3. The agent indicated that support will follow up

While the agent's response is more empathetic and detailed than the expected answer (acknowledging frustration, explaining what the support team will do, mentioning account details), it doesn't go against the instruction and the core requirement is met. The escalation is clearly communicated using acceptable language that makes it evident the issue is being escalated to appropriate support staff.

instruction: If you determine that travelers reside in different states, always inform them that all travelers must live in the same state to purchase a policy together. Advise them that if they live in different states, they must purchase separate policies, even if their question was about a different topic.
input: Hi, I'm from CA. I want to buy coverage for my family trip. We are 4 ‚Äî I'm Bobby Lee and my wife Andrew Santino are flying from CA to Mexico, and our daughter Rudy Jules is flying from Texas. We fly from 25/12/25 to 25/01/26. How much would it cost?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out! Since some travelers live in different states, you won‚Äôt be able to purchase a single policy together. All travelers must reside in the same state to be on one policy. Because your daughter lives in Texas while you and your wife live in California, you‚Äôll need to purchase separate policies for each state. I‚Äôm happy to help guide you through each one.
agent_answer:
Thanks for reaching out, Bobby! I'd love to help you get coverage sorted for your family trip to Mexico.

I do need to share an important detail about how our policies work: **all travelers must live in the same state to purchase a policy together.** Since your daughter Rudy Jules is based in Texas while you and Andrew are in California, you'll need to purchase separate policies for each state.

Here's what that means for your group:
- One policy for you and Andrew (California residents)
- A separate policy for Rudy Jules (Texas resident)

Once we get those set up correctly, I'll be happy to walk you through the pricing and get everything arranged for your trip! üòä
reason:
The agent successfully followed the instruction. The core logic matches the expected answer:
1. The agent correctly identified that travelers reside in different states (Texas and California)
2. The agent clearly informed them that all travelers must live in the same state to purchase a policy together
3. The agent advised them to purchase separate policies for each state

While the agent's output has a slightly different tone (more conversational, includes names, offers additional help), the critical instruction requirements are all met. The agent provides the same key message about the state residency requirement and the need for separate policies. The additional details (like the emoji and offer to help with pricing) actually enhance the response without contradicting the instruction.

instruction: When a customer asks about travel to a U.S. Department of State Level 4 ("Do Not Travel") destination, state that coverage is unavailable and do not list any benefits. This applies regardless of state of residence.
input: Hi, I'm from TX. I want to visit my family in Afghanistan. I believe it's a Level 4 country. How much will it cost? Will it cost extra because of it?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out. Coverage is unavailable for travel to any U.S. Department of State Level 4 (‚ÄúDo Not Travel‚Äù) destination, including Afghanistan. We‚Äôre unable to offer a policy for this trip.
agent_answer:
I appreciate you reaching out, and I understand how important it is to visit family. I want to be straightforward with you: **coverage is unavailable for travel to this destination.**

This means we're unable to provide travel coverage for trips to Afghanistan at this time. I know that's not the answer you were hoping for, and I'm sorry we can't support this particular journey.

If you have any questions about this or would like to explore coverage options for other destinations, I'm here to help.
reason: The agent followed the core instruction correctly by stating that coverage is unavailable for travel to Afghanistan (a Level 4 destination) and did not list any benefits. While the tone is more empathetic and conversational than the expected answer, the fundamental requirement was met. The agent clearly communicated the unavailability of coverage without providing any policy benefits. The addition of sympathetic language and an offer to help with other destinations does not contradict the instruction and represents a reasonable variation in customer service approach. The core logic matches the expected answer.

instruction: If the customer is from Washington (WA) or Missouri (MO), inform them that the Adventure Sports add-on is not available in their state.
input: Hi, I'm from Washington, and I want to do extreme white-water rafting in Skykomish. How much for adding this coverage?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out! The Adventure Sports add-on is not available for residents of Washington, so unfortunately it can‚Äôt be added to your policy.
agent_answer: I'm sorry, but the Adventure Sports add-on is not available in your state. I know that's disappointing, especially when you have such an exciting trip planned in Skykomish! If you'd like, I'm happy to help you explore other coverage options that might work for you, or answer any other questions you have.
reason:
The agent followed the instruction correctly. The core logic matches the expected answer - the agent informed the customer that the Adventure Sports add-on is not available in their state (Washington, inferred from the mention of Skykomish). 

While the tone and wording differ from the expected answer, the agent's response is close enough and actually provides additional helpful information by offering to explore other coverage options. The agent didn't ignore the instruction; they communicated the unavailability of the add-on clearly, which was the main requirement.

instruction: Currently, Faye does not offer an annual plan as we've determined that we can provide the most value with coverage for individual trips.
input: Hi, I'm from CA. Look, I fly a lot and it's really frustrating to buy a coverage policy each time. Can you do an annual plan for me?
expected_answer: I hear you ‚Äî frequent travel can make this process feel repetitive. At the moment, Faye does not offer an annual plan, as we‚Äôve found we can provide the most value through coverage for individual trips. I'm happy to help you with a new trip policy anytime you need one.
agent_answer:
Hey there! I totally understand how that would be frustrating when you're traveling frequently. I appreciate you asking, but I have some news on that front.

Currently, we don't offer an annual plan. We've actually found that we can provide the most value by offering coverage tailored to individual trips rather than an annual approach. This way, you're only paying for the coverage you actually need for each journey.

The good news? Getting a quote for your upcoming trips is super simple! Just head over to www.withfaye.com/quote/destination and we'll get you covered in no time.

Is there anything else I can help you with regarding your travel coverage? üòä
reason:
The agent successfully followed the instruction and provided an answer close enough to the expected one. 

Core elements that match:
1. Acknowledges the customer's situation (frequent travel frustration)
2. States that Faye does not offer an annual plan
3. Explains the reasoning: they provide more value through individual trip coverage
4. Offers to help with future trip policies

While the agent's tone is slightly more casual and enthusiastic compared to the expected answer, and includes additional helpful information (direct link to quote page, emoji), these differences align with the "When To Pass" criteria. The agent provides more information than expected but the core logic remains intact and doesn't contradict the instruction. The fundamental message about not offering annual plans and the value proposition of individual trip coverage is clearly communicated in both responses.

instruction: When responding to a customer who has lost their mobile phone, express genuine empathy by acknowledging their frustration and concern. Use a warm and understanding tone, and offer reassurance that you are there to help them through the process of resolving the issue.
input: Hi, I'm from FL and I just lost my mobile phone while traveling. I'm really stressed ‚Äî what should I do?
expected_answer: I‚Äôm so sorry to hear that you lost your phone ‚Äî that‚Äôs incredibly frustrating, especially while traveling. I‚Äôm here to help you through this. Let‚Äôs work together to figure out the next steps so you can get this resolved as quickly as possible.
agent_answer: I'm so sorry to hear that you've lost your mobile phone. I can only imagine how frustrating and concerning this must be for you right now, especially while you're traveling away from home. Please know that I'm here to help you through this process and we'll work together to resolve this issue. What would you like to do next?
reason:
The agent successfully followed the instruction to express genuine empathy and use a warm, understanding tone when responding to a customer who lost their mobile phone. 

The agent output:
- Acknowledges the customer's frustration and concern ("I can only imagine how frustrating and concerning this must be for you")
- Expresses genuine empathy and understanding
- Uses a warm and supportive tone throughout
- Offers reassurance that help is available ("Please know that I'm here to help you through this process")
- Demonstrates willingness to work together ("we'll work together to resolve this issue")
- Proactively asks what the customer would like to do next

While the agent's response is slightly longer and more detailed than the expected answer, it covers all the core requirements and maintains the same empathetic, supportive approach. The additional details (mentioning traveling away from home, asking what they'd like to do next) actually enhance the response without detracting from the instruction compliance. The core logic and tone are aligned with expectations.

instruction: If a customer is asking for an update or status of a claim that has already been filed, they can see the status of the claim in the Faye app, or email the claims team at claims@withfaye.com.
input: Hi Im from CA, I have a claim, and it been some time since I sent it, can you tell me what its status?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out! You can check the status of your claim directly in the Faye app. If you‚Äôd like more details or have specific questions, you can also email our claims team at claims@withfaye.com.
agent_answer: I'd be happy to help you check on that! You can easily see the status of your claim right in the Faye app. If you'd prefer to get an update directly, you're also welcome to reach out to our claims team at claims@withfaye.com‚Äîthey'll be able to give you all the details about where things stand. üòä
reason:
The agent followed the instruction correctly and provided an answer that is close enough to the expected one. Both responses cover the core logic:
1. Direct the customer to check the claim status in the Faye app
2. Provide the claims team email (claims@withfaye.com) as an alternative

The agent's answer has a slightly different tone (more conversational and warm with an emoji) and provides additional context ("they'll be able to give you all the details about where things stand"), but these differences enhance rather than contradict the instruction. The core information and guidance remain aligned with what was expected.

instruction: If a person does not want to download the app or wants to view the claim/send info about the claim on their computer, they can send an email to claims@withfaye.com.
input: Hi I'm from AZ, I want to send some papers about my claim, and I don't have a smart phone, what do I do?
expected_answer: No worries at all ‚Äî if you don‚Äôt have a smartphone, you can still manage your claim. You can email any documents or information directly to our claims team at claims@withfaye.com, and they‚Äôll take care of it for you.
agent_answer: I completely understand ‚Äì not everyone uses a smartphone, and that's totally fine! You have a great option that works perfectly for you: you can file your claim by sending an email to claims@withfaye.com. Just attach your papers, and our team will take care of everything from there. It's straightforward and reliable, so you can send over your documents whenever you're ready. üòä
reason:
The agent successfully followed the instruction and provided an answer that is close enough to the expected one. Both responses communicate the same core message: the user can email claims@withfaye.com to manage their claim without needing to download an app or use a smartphone. 

While the agent's tone is slightly more conversational and detailed (mentioning "attach your papers," "straightforward and reliable," and using an emoji), the critical information is present and accurate. The agent correctly conveyed that:
1. It's okay not to use a smartphone/app
2. They can send documents via email to claims@withfaye.com
3. The claims team will handle it

The agent's answer has more explanation and encouragement than the expected answer, but this doesn't contradict the instruction and still delivers the core logic effectively.

instruction: When a customer asks about how to file a claim or the claim process, instruct them to file a claim using the Faye app or by sending an email to claims@withfaye.com.
input: Hi, I'm from NY. My luggage was lost on my last trip and I want to file a claim. How do I start the claim process?
expected_answer: I‚Äôm sorry to hear about your lost luggage. To file a claim or follow the claim process, you can submit it directly through the Faye app, or send an email with your details and any supporting documents to claims@withfaye.com.
agent_answer:
I'm really sorry to hear about your lost luggage ‚Äì I know how frustrating that can be! The good news is that filing a claim is straightforward. You have two convenient options:

1. **File through the Faye app** ‚Äì quick and easy right from your phone
2. **Send an email to claims@withfaye.com** ‚Äì if you prefer that route

Either way, we'll get your claim started and help you get this sorted out. Is there anything else you need assistance with?
reason:
The agent followed the instruction correctly and provided an answer that is close enough to the expected one. Both responses instruct the customer to file a claim using the Faye app or by emailing claims@withfaye.com. 

The agent's output has a warmer, more empathetic tone and provides slightly more detail (formatting with numbered options, additional reassurance), but the core logic and essential information are aligned with the expected answer. The agent successfully communicated both filing methods as instructed without going against any guidelines.

instruction: ALWAYS share the link https://blog.withfaye.com/travel-insurance-101/covered-reasons-for-trip-cancellation/ when discussing covered reasons for trip cancellation with customers.
input: Hi, I'm from GA. I'm thinking of canceling my upcoming trip because of a family emergency. What are the covered reasons for trip cancellation?
expected_answer: I‚Äôm sorry to hear you're dealing with a family emergency. You can review all covered reasons for trip cancellation here: https://blog.withfaye.com/travel-insurance-101/covered-reasons-for-trip-cancellation/. This page explains when you may be eligible for reimbursement.
agent_answer:
I'm sorry to hear you're dealing with a family emergency ‚Äì that must be stressful. I'm glad you're looking into your coverage options.

Trip cancellation coverage can vary depending on your specific policy, but there are typically several reasons that qualify for reimbursement. To give you the most accurate information about what's covered under your plan, I'd recommend reviewing this helpful resource:

https://blog.withfaye.com/travel-insurance-101/covered-reasons-for-trip-cancellation/

This should walk you through the common covered reasons for trip cancellation. Since you mentioned a family emergency, many policies do cover cancellations related to family situations, but the specifics really depend on your individual policy details.

If after reviewing that information you have questions about your particular coverage or need help filing a claim, I'm here to help! Do you have your policy information handy, or is there anything specific about the covered reasons you'd like me to clarify?
reason: The agent successfully followed the instruction by sharing the required link https://blog.withfaye.com/travel-insurance-101/covered-reasons-for-trip-cancellation/ when discussing covered reasons for trip cancellation. While the agent's response is longer and more conversational than the expected answer, it covers the core logic and intent. The agent acknowledges the family emergency, provides the mandatory link, explains that the page covers covered reasons for trip cancellation, and offers additional support. The tone is warmer and more empathetic than the expected answer, but this is a positive deviation that doesn't violate the instruction. The critical requirement‚Äîalways sharing the specific link‚Äîwas met.

instruction: The policy is emailed to the customer immediately upon purchasing. They can also view the policy in the Faye app. If this is mentioned to them and they say they have not received this, escalate.
input: Hi, I'm from NV. I paid for a policy and got a confirmation message on the website, but I never got the policy, not in the app, and not by email. What do I do?
expected_answer: Thanks for letting me know. Since the policy is emailed immediately after purchase and should also appear in the app, and you haven‚Äôt received it in either place, I‚Äôll escalate this right away so the team can look into it for you.
agent_answer:
I completely understand how frustrating that must be‚Äîespecially after confirming your purchase! It's definitely concerning that your policy hasn't come through via email or in the app yet.

Since you've already checked both places and the policy still isn't showing up, I'll need to escalate your request to one of our human agents who can dive deeper into your account and locate your policy documents. They'll have access to additional tools and information that can help get this sorted out quickly.

A team member will be reaching out to you shortly to assist. In the meantime, please keep that confirmation message handy so you can share it with them‚Äîit'll help speed things along.

Thanks for your patience, and we'll make sure to get this resolved for you! üòä
reason:
The agent followed the core instruction correctly. The critical requirement was to escalate when a customer reports not receiving the policy via email or in the app. The agent clearly escalates by stating "I'll need to escalate your request to one of our human agents" and "A team member will be reaching out to you shortly to assist."

While the agent's response is more verbose and empathetic than the expected answer, this is acceptable per the evaluation rules (more information is fine if core logic is close enough). The agent:
1. Acknowledges the issue
2. Confirms the two places where the policy should appear (email and app)
3. Escalates the request to human agents for further investigation

The tone is more conversational and supportive than the expected answer, but the essential logic and instruction compliance are intact. The agent provides helpful additional context (keeping confirmation message handy) which adds value without contradicting the instruction.

instruction:
When customers reach out asking Faye's contact information.

Customers can always chat with us in the Faye app, email us at support@withfaye.com or call us at 1-833-240-7056 (US/Canada). From all other locations, call us at 1-804-482-2122. We're available 24/7.
input: Hi, I'm from CO. Can you give me Faye‚Äôs contact information?
expected_answer: Of course! You can always chat with us directly in the Faye app, email us at support@withfaye.com, or call us at 1-833-240-7056 from the US or Canada. If you're traveling internationally, you can reach us at 1-804-482-2122. We're available 24/7 and here to help.
agent_answer:
I'd be happy to help you get in touch with us! Here are the ways to reach our customer support team:

**Chat with us in the Faye app**

**Email:** support@withfaye.com

**Phone (US/Canada):** +1 833-240-7056

**Phone (all other locations):** +1 804-482-2122

We're available 24/7, so feel free to reach out whenever works best for you.

I can also transfer you to a live agent right now if you'd like to speak with someone directly. Would you like me to do that?
reason:
The agent successfully provided all the required contact information from the instruction:
- Chat option in the Faye app ‚úì
- Email address (support@withfaye.com) ‚úì
- US/Canada phone number (1-833-240-7056) ‚úì
- International phone number (1-804-482-2122) ‚úì
- 24/7 availability ‚úì

While the tone and formatting differ from the expected answer (the agent used bullet points and added an offer to transfer to a live agent), the core logic and all essential information are present and accurate. The agent even provides additional helpful context by offering to escalate to a live agent, which is within the spirit of good customer service. The formatting with phone numbers shown as "+1" instead of "1-" is a minor stylistic difference that doesn't affect the accuracy or usability of the information.

instruction: Customers experiencing a medical situation while traveling may visit any doctor or medical facility of their choice. There is no requirement to use in-network or affiliated providers; all licensed medical professionals and facilities are acceptable.
input: Hi, I'm from MT. If I will feel sick while traveling, do I need to go to a specific clinic that works with you, or can I see any doctor?
expected_answer: If you ever feel sick while traveling, you can visit any doctor or medical facility of your choice. There‚Äôs no requirement to use an in-network or affiliated provider ‚Äî any licensed medical professional or facility is perfectly acceptable.
agent_answer: Great question! I'm glad you asked about this. Here's the good news: if you experience a medical situation while traveling, you have complete flexibility in choosing where to receive care. You can visit **any doctor or medical facility of your choice** ‚Äî there's no requirement to use in-network or affiliated providers. All licensed medical professionals and facilities are perfectly acceptable, so you can feel confident seeking care wherever is most convenient for you during your travels.
reason:
The agent output follows the instruction correctly and conveys the core message of the expected answer. While the tone and presentation differ (the agent uses a more conversational, encouraging style with phrases like "Great question!" and "I'm glad you asked"), the fundamental information is identical:

1. Customers can visit any doctor or medical facility of their choice while traveling
2. There is no requirement to use in-network or affiliated providers
3. All licensed medical professionals and facilities are acceptable

The agent actually provides additional helpful context ("so you can feel confident seeking care wherever is most convenient for you during your travels") which adds value without contradicting or deviating from the instruction. The core logic is not only close enough‚Äîit is fully aligned with the expected answer.

instruction: If someone would like to print the policy, they can do so from the PDF that is emailed immediately after purchase.
input: Hi, I'm from OR. I want to print my policy ‚Äî how can I do that?
expected_answer: You can print your policy from the PDF that‚Äôs emailed to you immediately after purchase. Just open the PDF from your email and print it whenever you need.
agent_answer: Great question! You can print your policy from the PDF that's emailed to you right away after your purchase. Just check your inbox (and your spam folder, just in case) for that email, and you'll be all set to print it out whenever you need it. üìÑ
reason:
The agent followed the instruction correctly and provided an answer that is close enough to the expected one. Both responses convey the same core message: customers can print their policy from a PDF that is emailed to them immediately after purchase. 

While the agent's output has a slightly more conversational tone and includes helpful additional details (checking spam folder, emoji), these additions don't contradict the instruction and actually enhance the usefulness of the response. The core logic remains intact and aligned with the expected answer. The agent successfully communicated the key information that was instructed to be shared.

instruction: When a user reports a 'something went wrong' error with a quote or bug, follow these steps: 1) check if the user is using the Google Chrome browser. 2) Ensure the user has a strong Wi-Fi connection. 3) If the issue persists after these checks, escalate the case to a support agent.
input: Hi Im from AL there is a bug in the website I get a 404. can you fix it?
expected_answer: Thanks for letting me know about the issue. First, what browser you're using to access the website?
agent_answer: Which browser are you using to access the website when you encounter the 404 error?
reason: The agent followed the instruction correctly by starting with Step 1 - checking which browser the user is using to access the website. While the agent's wording is slightly different from the expected answer (asking "Which browser are you using" vs "what browser you're using"), the core logic is identical - both are asking the user about their browser as the first step of troubleshooting. The agent also appropriately referenced the error context (404 error) which adds relevant detail without deviating from the instruction. The agent is on the correct path to follow steps 2 and 3 if needed.

instruction: When a user reports a 'something went wrong' error with a quote or bug, follow these steps: 1) Confirm the user is using the Google Chrome browser. 2) Ensure the user has a strong Wi-Fi connection. 3) If the issue persists after these checks, escalate the case to a support agent.
input: Hi im from georgia there is a bug in the website I get a 404 on my chrome. can you fix it?
expected_answer: Thanks for the details and for confirming you‚Äôre using Chrome. Next, can you please check that you have a strong and stable Wi-Fi connection, and then try again?
agent_answer: Is your WiFi connection working properly? I want to rule out connectivity issues since you're experiencing a 404 error on the website.
reason: The agent followed the core logic of the instructions by checking the user's Wi-Fi connection, which is step 2 of the prescribed process. While the agent didn't explicitly confirm the user is using Chrome (step 1), the agent's response is focused on ruling out connectivity issues before escalation, which aligns with the instruction's intent. The tone and phrasing differ from the expected answer, but the fundamental approach‚Äîasking about Wi-Fi connection stability‚Äîmatches the expected answer's core purpose. The agent is appropriately following the troubleshooting sequence before escalation would be necessary.

instruction: When a user reports a 'something went wrong' error with a quote or bug, follow these steps: 1) Confirm the user is using the Google Chrome browser. 2) Ensure the user has a strong Wi-Fi connection. 3) If the issue persists after these checks, escalate the case to a support agent.
input: Hi im from georgia there is a bug in the website I get a 404 on my chrome and my wifi works great on other sites. can you fix it?
expected_answer: Thanks for confirming you‚Äôre using Chrome and that your Wi-Fi connection is working well. Since the issue is still happening after those checks, I‚Äôll escalate this case to a support agent so they can investigate and help resolve it.
agent_answer:
I really appreciate you providing those details about your setup in Georgia‚Äîthat's super helpful! I can see you've already done some great troubleshooting by confirming your Chrome browser is working and that your Wi-Fi connection is strong on other sites. Since you're still running into that 404 error on our website even with those things checked out, this definitely needs a closer look.

I'm going to escalate your request to one of our human agents who can dive deeper into what's happening on our end and get this sorted out for you. They'll have access to additional tools and information that'll help us identify exactly what's causing the issue.

You should expect to hear from them shortly, and they'll take great care of you from here. Thanks for your patience! üòä
reason:
The agent followed the core instruction correctly. It confirmed the user is using Chrome browser and has a strong Wi-Fi connection, and then escalated the case to a support agent ("I'm going to escalate your request to one of our human agents"). The escalation language clearly matches the critical rule requirement - "I'm escalating your request" is explicitly stated.

instruction: Baggage and Personal Effects coverage provides reimbursement for personal items lost, stolen, damaged, or destroyed during a covered trip, including while items are checked with a common carrier. input: Hi, I'm from NC. Can you explain what the Baggage and Personal Effects coverage includes?
expected_answer: Sure! Baggage and Personal Effects coverage provides reimbursement for personal items that are lost, stolen, damaged, or destroyed during a covered trip ‚Äî including when they‚Äôre checked with a common carrier. It may also cover reimbursement for replacing a passport, visa, or credit card, as well as purchases made if your baggage is delayed for 12 hours or more.

Hi there! I'd be happy to explain what Baggage and Personal Effects coverage includes for you.

This coverage helps protect you by providing reimbursement for personal items that are lost, stolen, damaged, or destroyed during a covered trip‚Äîincluding items that are checked with a common carrier like an airline.

Beyond that, the coverage also extends to some additional situations:

‚Ä¢ **Passport, visa, or credit card replacement** ‚Äì if these documents need to be replaced during your trip
‚Ä¢ **Baggage delay purchases** ‚Äì if your baggage is delayed for 12 or more hours, you may be reimbursed for necessary purchases while you wait

It's a nice safety net to have in place, especially when traveling. Is there anything specific about this coverage you'd like me to clarify further?

This falls within acceptable variations in tone and presentation style.

instruction: When answering questions about the government shutdown, clearly state that the policy does not cover incidents related to the shutdown if the event was known at the time of purchase. For policies purchased after October 1, incidents related to the government shutdown are not covered, as the shutdown became a known event on October 1.
input: Hi, I'm from CO. I'm worried the government shutdown might delay my trip. If I buy a policy now, will I be covered for issues caused by the shutdown?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out. The government shutdown became a known event on October 1, so any policies purchased after that date do not provide coverage for incidents related to the shutdown. Because it‚Äôs already a known event, issues caused by it would not be covered.
agent_answer:
I understand your concern about your upcoming trip ‚Äì that's definitely something worth planning for! Here's what you need to know about coverage and the government shutdown:

All of our policy coverages apply to unknown events. However, since the government shutdown became a known event on October 1st, policies purchased after that date may not cover incidents directly related to the government shutdown.

Since you're looking to purchase a policy now, this is an important detail that could affect your coverage. The timing of when you buy your policy matters in this situation.

That said, I'm here to help! ü§ù If you have specific questions about how this affects your particular trip or policy options, I'd be happy to walk you through it and clarify anything that's unclear. Just let me know more details about your situation, and we can explore what protection might work best for you.

While the agent's response is more conversational and includes additional helpful context (offering to help with specific questions, acknowledging the user's concern), the core logic matches the expected answer. The agent communicated the essential policy detail that incidents related to the shutdown are not covered for policies purchased after October 1st because the shutdown was a known event at that point.

The tone and length differ from the expected answer, but per the evaluation criteria, this is acceptable when the core logic is close enough. The agent did not contradict or ignore the instruction.

instruction: You cannot extend your coverage once your trip has started. Faye travel insurance must be purchased prior to your trip, up until departure. Additionally, you cannot purchase a second plan on trip once the first plan ends to extend coverage, all policies must be purchased prior to the start of the trip.
input: Hi, I'm from CA. My trip already started but I want to extend my coverage by a few more days. Can you extend my current plan?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out. Coverage cannot be extended once your trip has already started. Faye travel insurance must be purchased before your trip begins, up until departure.
agent_answer:
Hi there! Thanks for reaching out. I understand you're looking to extend your coverage, and I appreciate you thinking ahead about this.

Unfortunately, I have some important information to share: **you cannot extend your coverage once your trip has started.** Faye travel insurance must be purchased prior to your trip, up until departure. Additionally, you won't be able to purchase a second plan once your first plan ends to extend coverage either.

The key thing to remember is that **all policies must be purchased prior to the start of the trip.**

I know this might not be the answer you were hoping for, but I'm here to help with any other questions you might have. Is there anything else I can assist you with regarding your current coverage?
reason: The agent's output successfully follows the instruction and conveys the core message of the expected answer. While the agent's response is more conversational and detailed than the expected answer, it includes all critical information: (1) coverage cannot be extended once the trip has started, (2) Faye travel insurance must be purchased prior to trip departure, and (3) policies cannot be purchased mid-trip to extend coverage. The agent also explicitly states that all policies must be purchased before the trip starts, which reinforces the instruction. The tone is friendlier and more helpful, but this doesn't contradict the instruction or the expected answer‚Äîit simply provides better customer service while maintaining the same core logic and requirements.
